timeline.message:
Add public Samplers.emptyDecision(boolean).

This is meant for use by custom Sampler implementations. As of now, you have to use an anonymous inner class or otherwise derive a new class because there is no publicly accessible implementation of Decision.

Add Samplers.decision(boolean, Map).

Co-authored-by: Bogdan Drutu <bogdandrutu@gmail.com>

Add Samplers.decision(boolean, Map).

Co-authored-by: Bogdan Drutu <bogdandrutu@gmail.com>

timeline.bodyText: Just having this note in here, rather than copying the attributes, feels too weak. If having the map be non-modified is truly a hard requirement, the API should protect itself, rather than relying on implementors to read this javadoc.
timeline.author: jkwatson
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -63,6 +64,45 @@ // No instance of this class. private Samplers() {} + /** + * Returns a {@link Decision} with the given {@code attributes} and {@link Decision#isSampled()} + * returning {@code isSampled}. + * + *

This is meant for use by custom {@link Sampler} implementations. + * + *

Using {@link #emptyDecision(boolean)} instead of this method is slightly faster and shorter + * if you don't need attributes. + * + * @param isSampled The value to return from {@link Decision#isSampled()}. + * @param attributes The attributes to return from {@link Decision#getAttributes()}. A different + * object instance with the same elements may be returned. The map must not be modified after + * being passed to this function. Use {@link Collections#emptyMap()} for an empty decision.

replies.bodyText:
First, I think this is an SDK-only API that will only be used by sampler implementations. An "advanced" API so to speak. If I knew that this function was uselessly copying my map, I would rather write my own replacement for efficiency.
Second, in the currently only usage of the Sampler the attributes are actually copied into the span right-away, so I think ignoring this note won't actually do any harm.
replies.author: Oberon00

replies.bodyText: Then the word "must" here seems overly strong, and possibly misleading. Can you update the javadoc to reflect the reality of the situation?
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: Hmm, I wouldn't place too much value on the second point, as the usage of the sampler may change in the future. So anyone who reads the javadoc certainly MUST NOT modify this later.
replies.author: Oberon00

replies.bodyText: All I'm saying is: If this is an important constraint, then we should either a) enforce it via code or b) clearly explain what the ramifications of violating it are, and not just mention it offhand in attribute documentation.
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText: Unfortunately I think a) is not possible without losing efficiency. And I think with b) we would over-constrain ourselves regarding future changes.
replies.author: Oberon00

replies.bodyText:
How about adding a line to the javadoc, not in the attributes section like this:
You should not modify the contents of the attributes after passing them to this function. If you modify the contents of the attributes after passing them to this function, behavior is not well defined.
replies.author: jkwatson

replies.bodyText:
a) is not possible without losing efficiency.

Confused about this, you should cache the result if performance is important, otherwise it is good to have your own implementation of the Decision where you ensure the immutable part differently.
Having an API that relies on these kind of comments is not safe and we cannot guarantee correctness (we can NLP or other exceptions if the user changes the map while we are reading it).
replies.author: bogdandrutu

replies.bodyText:
you should cache the result if performance is important

Good point actually. I think you convinced me that it is better to copy the attributes after all. I will add this to Decision.create.
replies.author: Oberon00

replies.bodyText: Done! I used ImmutableMap.copyOf and also fixed the javadoc.
replies.author: Oberon00
